content: Ya gotta admit, the Wicca thing is a lot funnier than some religions. ********************************* Witches, ghost hunters gather in Salem By Associated Press Monday, April 20, 2009 SALEM — Dozens of witches, psychics and ghost hunters in Salem have finished two conventions on the "paranormal world." GhoStock 7 — a four-day conference for paranormal investigators — ended Sunday after a group of ghost hunters searched for spirits at local hot spots like the Hawthorne Hotel’s basement. Others presented photos of what they believed to be ghosts. The Illinois-based Witch School International also wrapped up its "three days of Wicca, Witchcraft and High Ritual" gathering. Attendees had lunch from a "Bewitched Menu," containing items served during filming of the Salem episodes of the TV show "Bewitched" 40 years ago. Both conferences attracted people from around the country.

content: From WHAS 11 News: Witches, magic and spells: Wiccan religion fact and fiction 11:48 AM EDT on Saturday, April 25, 2009 (WHAS11) - Witches, magic and spells - there’s more to the growing Wiccan religion than what you’ve seen or read. WHAS11’s Adrianna Hopkins talked to a local witch to dispel the myth. We take you behind the magic and show you why this religion has cast its spell on Louisville. “Things are not quite what they seem.” Forget what you’ve seen on TV. “Can we ride brooms? No. We can’t ride brooms.” Walk into Linda Tipton’s store “Moonstruck” and amid the altars, the candles, the herbs and the statues. Linda Tipton said, “We can’t fly; we can’t jump from place to place; I can’t twitch my nose and clean my house - I wish I could! It’d be great!” Linda’s store has all things pagan. Linda Tipton said, “Paganism is real hard to explain. It doesn’t mean ungodly. It doesn’t mean that you don’t believe in any god. Most pagans believe in more than one god.” Linda Tipton said, “I was always interested in what you might call the cult things. I was always fascinated with witches and that kind of thing.” The worship tools you’ll find for sale are quite different from what she used to use. Linda Tipton said, “I grew up Christian. Disciples of Christ. I was at one time a Sunday School teacher, Choir Director, Children’s Choir Director. Sang in the choir myself. Was very active in church.” But at 17 years old, she scratched the itch and explored. She found a book about witches and witchcraft and before she knew it, she was spellbound. Linda Tipton said, “In Wicca, there is not a Jesus Christ or a Christ figure; there is no actual set book that we call our Bible; most Wiccans don’t believe in the devil; there is no version of sin. We don’t speak of sin,” Tipton explains. “There are spells and the best way to think about spells is they’re like prayers. They’re like petitions to the god and goddess. We do believe there is a place we go when we pass on. Our Wiccans call it ‘Summerland.’” Tipton says, Wicca is a “nature religion” and witches are “stewards of the Earth.” They see it as a living being. Linda also says the “craft” is centuries old—and the salvation for her agricultural Celtic ancestors. Linda Tipton said, “They had a great understanding of the season and of the animals and the plants and how it all interconnected.” The magic is still there. Hundreds of pagans gather for seasonal festivals throughout Kentucky. But like other religions, not everyone tolerates their beliefs. “There are many people who still think that wiccans are devil worshippers,” says Linda. “Be very careful not to judge other people until you really understand where they’re coming from because Christ said ‘judge not lest you be judged.” One of the pagan seasonal festivals, “Beltane,” is coming up May 1st, 2nd and 3rd. The festival is a celebration of the god and goddess and their union.
